DOC.HEAD: China, U.S. Hold Talks On Resuming Fulbrights
DOC.TEXT: China and the United States said today they have opened talks on resuming the Fulbright scholar exchange program, a victim of the chill in relations after China's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. China's State Education Commission and the U.S. Embassy said their representatives met for the first time last week _ just days after U.S. National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft's fence-mending visit to Beijing. Neither side linked the talks to Scowcroft's visit, but embassy spokesman Ed Loo acknowledged, ``There wasn't much going on before.'' He said the United States had been seeking a renewal of the government-sponsored Fulbright program ``for some time.'' China announced this fall that it was halting the program for a year, apparently because of anger over U.S. condemnation of its June army attack on students protesting for democratic reform. It also canceled plans to accept Peace Corps volunteers. In other signs of a warming between the two countries since Scowcroft visited with Undersecretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, China has indicated it is open to a negotiated settlement for Fang Lizhi, the Chinese dissident who took refuge in the U.S. Embassy. It has also said it will allow the U.S. government radio station, the Voice of America, to send a new bureau chief to Beijing. China expelled the former bureau chief, Al Pessin, in June, accusing him of distorting facts and violating martial law imposed during the protests. Reception of VOA Chinese-language broadcasts also has become much clearer in the past week, although it is not clear if the Chinese have halted all jamming. English-language broadcasts have not been jammed. An official in the International Department of the State Education Commission, who did not give his name, said China has not yet decided if it will resume Fulbright exchanges. He refused to say if China wants to change the terms of the program. ``We are talking about both sides' plans and conceptions,'' he said. ``We originally halted it for a year, 1989 to 1990. Now we are talking about restoring it for 1990-91.'' Under the program, which exchanges American and foreign scholars worldwide, two dozen American scholars lecture at Chinese universities and a dozen Chinese scholars and a dozen students visit the United States for research and studies. China has taken part in the Fulbright program since shortly after U.S.-Chinese relations were established in 1979. Scowcroft's visit has been criticized by some congressmen and commentators in the United States as coming too soon after China's bloody crackdown, in which hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed. The Bush administration had halted all high-level visits in June and imposed several other sanctions, including halting military sales. However, it vetoed legislation that would have expanded the sanctions and required the president to report to Congress before lifting them. The administration has argued that Bush's softer approach and his sending of Scowcroft will encourage China to improve its human rights performance.
